comments.commentBody: Where is Obama? His silence is deafening!
Which way does Sanders have to wave his arms to get you to vote for him?
I believe that Sanders is more likely than any other candidate to try to make fundemental changes to American policing.

Notice the ONLY presidential candidate to take a stand against this is Bernie Sanders who said he will FUNDAMENTALLY change policing in America so another Tamir Rice child MURDER won't happen again.

ALL the other candidates are silent.

Sanders has the solution to prevent future child killing cops getting away with murder.

Not Clinton, Bush, Trump, Cruz, Rubio.

Seems only Sanders cares about regular American children getting murdered by the cops at the playground.

We are scoffed at by the rest of the world. If I were a European, I would have no desire to visit the United States.  If I was not a senior with a disabled daughter, I would be looking into a move outside of this country.
I think most Americans just don't understand how hostile American policing appears to the rest of the world.
They did not say the child was at playground recreation center at least.

Headline in today's Le Monde , France

"Le policier américain qui a tué un enfant jouant avec un faux pistolet ne sera pas poursuivi"

(The American policeman who killed a child playing with a fake gun will not be prosecuted).

It is headline like this, that convince many Europeans that US is not a civilized country. No police in Europe would act in such a manner.
The killing of Tamir Rice was not a "tragic accident." it was, at the very least, manslaughter for the two police to shoot the boy and then refuse to render aid to to him.

The author of this article makes a fundament mistake. Cancer drugs are tested on late-stage cancer patients for various reasons (including convenience). But these drugs are intended for use in earlier stage cancers. The hope is that a drug that's shown to extend the life of a stage IV patient by a few months will cure patients with early-stage disease. Stage IV patients are the guinea pigs used to test drugs that will eventually be used to treat early-stage cancers.

This article misses the point. We cancer doctors and researchers test drugs on patients with higher recurrence and progression rates because that's the only reasonable population to test them in. If they work in that setting, drugs then move to the non-recurrent setting (ie front line) to be tested. If they work there, then they can be tried in the secondary prevention setting. This article misses the fact that we intentionally design the trial portfolio to have more drugs being tested in the recurrent setting where we can get results rapidly. Not to mention, these are the patients who really need access to those drugs immediately.

They already paid retributions in the past. Made apologizes over and over again. Even its own citizens paying a price during Japan's last days of the war. It's only China and Korea that can't get over it. The rest of Asia is allying themselves with Japan now.

These repo men seem like folk heros, taking back stolen goods or fighting corrupt officials.  And doing so without weapons or violence?  That's rather amazing given the rest of this series, it seems like 12 miles out is exactly where you can't count on anyone playing by anybody's rules except who has a bigger gun.

Was wondering when we'd get around to blaming the union for doing what it was supposed to so, which is defending the right to a process, not defending the cops involved.

Justice is honest process, not the outcome you want. You got a real reason to thing the process was dishonest? Other than not getting what you want?

These are the kind of fools being hired to be OUR law enforcement officers and given guns?  Seriously?  And they are being protected by their "blue line union"?  Now there is a union that needs to be disbanded.

Yes, G-man, it's Eli that's to blame. But you won't hear that mentioned anywhere. Somehow the blame always gets shifted to someone else. This week it's Coughlin as if he threw the two interceptions in the Viking game. Always heard is that Eli is a "two time Super Bowl winner" as if he did it all by himself. Well, how about "four time EFP" --  eliminated from playoffs. He's not professional grade and never was compared to other QBs in the NFL. He can thank the well connected Archie for the job he has. It was never earned on merit. Now Giant management can live with his $84 million contract.

What am i missing,,,?
63.1 4134 33 14 93.6
You Giant fans kill me!!! TC/EM win you two Super Bowls with mediocre teams and you all sell them out the first chance you get!  Go Jets!

Yes, Reese needs to go; absolutely terrible! Coughlin is not to blame, it's Eli. Two super bowl wins buys you a couple of mulligans but for each great play there are a dozen of bone headed ones. How many game killing interceptions and  poor clock management decisions do we need to see from this "elite QB"? He received a new contract and has not proved his worth and what's the deal with JPP? Reese needs to go!!!!

Coughlin's nobility as a head coach and as a human being will outlive the sting of his inevitable resignation/dismissal. He certainly cannot control the curse of injuries that have beset this team over the years, but he must bear responsibility for the  culture of mistakes this team makes game after game- missed assignments, poor route running, inability to catch the football, lack of fundamentals particularly in tackling and  the elusive screen pass. Change does not always produce wonders,  but I don't think we fans can endure another year of unforced errors and self inflicted losses with this cast of characters and we can hope that there's another gentleman giant out there to push the reset button for this proud franchise.

The Giants lack talent and depth on the defensive side (and running back as well). Here is where most games were lost. I blame Reese more than Coughlin, but I'm not sure if Coughlin  has enough years to last a rebuild.

You do realize that your so called "Big Brother America" led Japan to Imperialistic dreams. Teddy Roosevelt wanted Japan to occupy Korea, win the war against Russia, and he wanted Japan to be the sphere of influence in East Asia not Russia. Also Japan paid retributions and apologized over and over in the past. I haven't heard America apologize during its occupation of the Philippines before WW2. Every nation has blood on its hand.

You misread the document. It ordered the police to crack down on comfort station owners' agents who were engaging in illegal recruiting.

My argument is not based solely on anecdotal testimonies.

How do you explain the existence of a diary written by a Korean comfort station worker in which he explained Korean comfort women were the sex slaves of Korean comfort station owners?

http://book.daum.net/detail/book.do?bookid=KOR9788994228761

How do you explain the existence of articles in Korean newspapers in the 1930's & 1940's in which they said Korean women were abducted by Korean comfort station owners' agents?

http://gall.dcinside.com/board/view/?id=history&no=1283822

Unless you can answer these questions, you have lost the argument.

By the way, I have dozens of other primary sources that you won't be able to explain if you want to keep arguing.
You do realize Japan paid retributions in the past right? Which surely surpassed this amount. It's not Japan's fault the Korean govt back then didn't use the money for the correct purpose.
Thank you!!!!!!
If Japan is sincere in her remorse on the issue, she should welcome Koreans’ discussion on the issue and, in her own country, making it a crime to deny Comfort Woman.

Two things:
1) Why did the money from the sellout not go directly to the bank accounts of the "comfort women"(or families of victims)?

2) To those outraged at the Korean government for selling out their own people's suffering, what would have been the better alternative than money? If there was still peace talks about the Japan's horrid mistakes, what would you rather have to compensate for it (if there is any "compensation" at all)?

Ignorance is bliss but best not paraded openly.  German remorse extends to making it a crime to deny the holocaust.  Japan on the other hand actively revises history books erasing any suggestion of imperial belligerence, war atrocity, even suggesting the attack on Pearl Harbor is an American fiction.  Any reason you feel such empathy for a government that refuses to acknowledge responsibility for crimes against victims still living?

Well how would you feel if there was a statue of a Native American under a blanket with smallpox, or of a Filipino being water boarded outside of the US Embassy, or an African in chains, how about a statue of Hawaiians dying after having their islands stolen? How would you feel if you had a statue dedicated to your country's past mistakes?
It's because Germany doesn't have a China or Korea that keeps bringing it up every year.

The stimulus of WW2 is what really ended the Depression.
That stimulus was about double the 1929 GDP or triple the 1937 GDP.
We needed the stimulus to be much bigger.

Double the 2007 GDP of 14.49 trillion would be 29 trillion -- 29,000 billion
The amount of the stimulus that was devoted to directly creating demand -- construction was about 300 billion -- about 1% -- one percent -- of what was really needed. 500 billion was spent to fund unemployment comp and to keep state local teachers and uniformed personnel on the job.

300 billion spent versus 30,000 billion required to do the job.
Never has funding only 1% of the job been anywhere near as successful.
President Obama did very well for all of us with far, far too little resources.

Since 2008, we have been successful, but on the cheap. Because the stimulus was just 1% of what was really needed, our accumulated GDP shortfall is over 10 trillion. Also, 10 million people have left the workforce who would otherwise be employed full time.

Make America Great Again - send DT and every other republican/libertarian/tea party and other ALEC/Koch brothers operative back where they came from.  Sorry, Canada - you get Cruz back.

They don't have to call your mother, because they already know EVERYTHING about you.

No, ur wrong. The Calif. couple were NOT citizens. He was, but not his wife. She was a legal resident with a visa, but it was improperly vetted.

Two of the Paris bombers were not citizens, but entered the EU fraudulently, with many other refugees. The goats of the EU admit they don't really know who these refugees are. Some of them have false passports and many are undocumented.

Obviously, Jad Mouawad is unaware of the fact that the terrorist events in Paris and California were executed by citizens. In Europe, each citizen has a national ID card. It didn't prevent the terrorist attack from taking place there. The California couple were citizens of the US. The husband was born in the United States and his wife had been investigated by the the government as well.

It's sort of obvious to me that no amount of investigation and no kind of ID is going to ferret-out terrorists. The notion that one can be absolutely safe from danger is an irrational notion. There is no "utopia." The word itself mean "no place." Over time, we have modified the definition of the word to mean just the opposite and coined the word "dystopia" to mean what "utopia" already means. Neither society exists, though there are some that come close.

We need to wake up to the reality of the times in which we live. Life without insecurity is an illusion.

As a Minnesotan, I know that the people here who have blocked the ID issue are both conservative Republicans and liberal Democrats.  It is simply false to suggest that they want "to do us, as Americans, harm."  You may not agree with them, I may not agree with them -- but this sort of baseless claim does not help us discuss where lines of privacy and security should be drawn.
